talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 1 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) Were sums allocated in the 2000-2001 Budget for the purposes of insulating houses adversely affected by aircraft noise in the vicinity of domestic and international airports; if so, (a) where and (b) what is the associated cost and timeframe for the project.
(2) If sums were not allocated, are there plans to allocate sums in future Budgets.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) and (2) Sums were allocated in the 2000-2001 Budget for the purposes of insulating houses adversely affected by aircraft noise in the vicinity of both Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and Adelaide Airport.

An amount of $64.892m was allocated for Sydney in anticipation of works being completed by the end of June 2001. Timing will, however, be dependent on the response of building owners to offers of assistance.

An amount $10.27m was allocated for Adelaide in respect of 2000-2001, with works commencing late in 2000. A total estimate of $63.749m has been provided over four years with the Program expected to be completed during the 2003-2004 financial year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 1 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) Must B Double trucks travelling north to Brisbane and other main centres use the New England Highway, despite the ongoing upgrade of the Pacific Highway.
(2) At what stage is Government consideration of the Maitland by-pass and what is the estimated cost of the by-pass.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

quote.para: (1) The New South Wales Roads and Traffic Authority (RTA) has advised that due to progress with the jointly funded Pacific Highway Upgrading Program,
B-Doubles can now travel on the Pacific Highway between Hexham and Ballina, and between Murwillumbah and Queensland,
However, B-Doubles are restricted from travelling between Ballina and Murwillumbah because of conditions at Burringbar Range. Consequently,
B-Doubles travelling between Sydney and Brisbane must use the New England Highway.

To bypass the Burringbar Range, construction has commenced on dual carriageways between Yelgun and Chinderah. This work is jointly funded by the Federal and NSW Governments, and completion is planned for end 2002. The RTA will then reassess the use of the Pacific Highway by B-Doubles between Ballina and Murwillumbah.
(2) The RTA has been planning a long-term National Highway link between the F3 and the New England Highway at Branxton (part of which includes a “Maitland Outer Bypass”) since 1993.

However, a range of issues have arisen during environmental assessment of the preferred route and, as a result, the route is yet to be determined by the NSW Government. The RTA advises that route determination is now expected in 2001.

The Government has allocated $0.2 million in the 2000/2001 budget for the project and will continue to fund planning. Further consideration will be given to the funding and timing of construction, as well as possible staging options, when planning work is more advanced.

Preliminary estimates of costs provided by the RTA indicate that to complete Stages 1 and 2 of the F3 to Branxton route would cost in the vicinity of $250 million. Stage 1 together with upgrading of John Renshaw Drive (which would provide an outer bypass of Maitland), are estimated to cost around $115 million.

Since these cost estimates were originally provided several years ago, the Commonwealth has asked the RTA to confirm the expected costs of the entire project and to provide more detailed explanation of how they are derived.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 5 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) Will he announce a decision on a second airport for Sydney at Badgerys Creek on or before 1 September 2000.

(2) Further to his answer to part (1) of question No.1440 (Hansard, 29 May 2000, page 15615), what are the details of the minor impact the implementation of The Australian Advanced Air Traffic System will have on the Long Term Operating Plan at Sydney over the period from the end of July 1999 to mid October 1999.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Government is currently considering the complex issues linked to Sydney's future airport needs, and expects to make a decision on these issues in the near future.
(2) Airservices Australia advise the following:
Transition of Sydney Airport to a TAAATS environment occurred in 3 stages:
. Departures - 24 July 1999
. Approach - 31 August 1999
. Complete Transition - 11 September 1999.

During the transition period to Departures, runway changes at Sydney Airport were kept to only those absolutely necessary for the first 3 days. This resulted in Sydney airport operating on either R16 or R34 parallel operations for the most part during this period, with crossing runway modes being used only during quiet periods.

After the Departures transition phase, Airservices adhered as much as possible to the nominal runway mode change times for the remainder of the transition to TAAATS while Air Traffic Controllers became used to the new operating environment.

subdebateinfo.title: UNESCO Convention on Higher Education in Asia and the Pacific: Australian Ratification
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1604)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 2000:

(3) On what occasions has Australia raised the question with each of the States referred to in part (2).

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Australia became a party to the Convention through deposit of an instrument of acceptance on 23 September 1985.
(3) Australia has not formally raised the question.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 7 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) Did the 1991 Special Premiers' Conference agree that road funding should be based on the Commonwealth Government being responsible for national roads, State Governments being responsible for arterial roads and local governments being responsible for local roads.

(2) What understandings were reached with State and local governments associated with the Government's new taxation system in the context of the government response to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform Planning not Patching report.

(3) Does the Government response at page 41 state that the (a) new taxation system provides an important devolution of financial independence to the States, Territories and local government for the road program and (b) Government provides an appropriate level of funding in the Budget for its road program; if so, how does this reconcile with the agreements from the 1991 Special Premiers' Conference and calls to improve local roads and bridge infrastructure throughout Australia, particularly in rural and regional areas.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) That is a summary of the 1991 agreement in relation to road funding.
(2) No understandings were reached with State and local governments in the context of the Government's response to the Planning not Patching Report.
(3) The response to the Planning not Patching Report is consistent with the 1991 Agreement and the new taxation arrangements.

The 1991 Agreement apportioned responsibility for road funding to the appropriate level of government. The Commonwealth continues to directly fund the National Highway and other roads of national importance, which are the roads for which it is responsible. It provides an appropriate level of funding to meet its responsibilities. Other levels of government fund the roads for which they are responsible.

The Commonwealth does assist other levels of government to meet their responsibilities but does not assume responsibility for local roads and bridge infrastructure. The Commonwealth is providing over $1.32b in assistance to local government in 2000-01. $30m has been offered to the States and Territories to assist with bridge upgrading on strategic freight routes off the National Highway to facilitate the implementation of higher mass limits for heavy vehicles.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 20 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) What sum would it cost to upgrade the section of the Calder Highway between Woodend and Kyneton to dual carriageway standard.
(2) What is the cost of upgrading the bridges on this section of the highway.
(3) Are there plans to complete the upgrade of this section of highway; if so, when is it scheduled to commence.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) $50 million (1999 dollars)
(2) $11.8 million (1999 dollars)
(3) The Federal Government is committed to progressive upgrading of the Calder Highway, subject to the availability of funds.
The Calder Highway is a state arterial and the responsibility of the Victorian Government. I understand that the Victorian Government has allocated some funding for the Woodend to Kyneton section.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 20 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn by the Victorian Roads Alliance that Victoria contributes 25% of the nations fuel excise, accounts for 25% of national road usage, yet receives only 15% of Federal road funding.
(2) Is there any basis to the claim; if so; are Victorians deprived of $130 million additional road funding per annum.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes. The Municipal Association of Victoria has written to the Federal Government on behalf of the Victorian Roads Alliance.
(2) No. The Victorian Roads Alliance's claim misguidedly compares fuel excise collection with road funding. There is no relationship between these two issues.
Victoria receives a high level of direct Federal road funding commensurate with the length and Importance of the State's National Highway and Roads of National Importance systems.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 21 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has Radio Australia's service been of enormous importance in enhancing understanding of international relations for people in the Asian region and beyond and generating goodwill between people of diverse ethnic and religious communities living under a range of political systems.

(2) Has Radio Australia been very important in fostering greater understanding through the support it has given to international conferences and meetings, such as the religion and culture in the Asia Pacific - Violence or healing conference to be held in Melbourne in October.
(3) Will the decision to cut the services of Radio Australia be reconsidered.
(4) Will the decision to sell the Radio Australia transmitter to a private organisation be reconsidered.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Radio Australia continues to provide an important service in the Asia Pacific region as it has done over an extended period of time.

(2) See response to question 1. Radio Australia regularly participates in meetings of regional broadcasting associations (such as the Asia-Pacific Broadcasting Union and Pacific Islands Broadcasting Association) and organises seminars with Australian universities on Asian-related topics.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Sport and Tourism, upon notice, on 22 June 2000:

quote.para: Further to the answer to question No. 1480 (Hansard, 31 May 2000, page 15813), would she provide a breakdown of the funding provided by the Government under the Indigenous Sport Program setting out, in particular, desired outcomes and parameters of the program.

talker.name: Kelly, Jackie, MP
Miss Jackie Kelly
talker.role: Minister for Sport and Tourism and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Further to my response to Parliamentary Question on Notice No. 1480 the $257,433 provided in 1999-2000 to the Northern Territory for the Indigenous Sport Program (ISP) is used to employ 4 regional development officers.

The ISP is a joint initiative of the Australian Sports Commission (ASC) and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. The Program aims to improve Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander participation in sport and recreation with a specific community development focus. The ISP strategy is founded on the principles of self-determination and self-management which sees Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders working for Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders from a community level through to the ASC's management of the strategy.
The ISP consists of a number of specific schemes or development tools:
. Indigenous Community Sport Development Program
. National Elite Indigenous Travel and Accommodation Assistance Program
. Regional Indigenous Sport Assistance Program
. Cross Cultural Awareness Training
. Athlete Development Initiative, including:
Olympic Training Centre Scholarships;
Indigenous Sport Scholarships;
Uluru Athletes Forum; and
Googlagong Sports Libraries.
The ASC and ATSIC are currently involved in negotiations to expand the ISP in the Northern Territory.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Self Funded Retirees Compensation Package
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1663)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 22 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) What information was provided to self funded retirees who are on a part pension about their eligibility for the GST compensation package.
(2) When and how was the information provided.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

entry.para: Articles outlining changes to pensions, personal taxes and the Saving Bonuses for older Australians.

Age Pension NewsAge Pension News is a quarterly publication from Centrelink covering issues relevant to age pensioners. It is delivered to the homes of age pensioners and has a distribution of around two million.

Representatives of peak welfare organisations, including for self-retirees, were given the opportunity to attend a one day seminar. All compensatory aspects of tax reform were covered and attendees were provided with an information kit that included the material on computer disk. The expected outcome of the seminar was that peak bodies would be able to disseminate information about taxation reform to their members.
One day seminar held in Canberra.
An article to help age pensioners understand how the Goods and Services Tax (GST) will affect health-related goods and services.
Detailed articles covering the general impact of tax reform, the compensation available, personal tax changes and the Savings Bonuses for Older Australians.
Press advertisements targeted to age pensioners and self-funded retirees.
Television advertisements targeted to age pensioners and self-funded retirees.

The Information Kits contain overviews and fact sheets about the portfolio's tax reform measures, such as the restructure of family assistance, compensation available to pensioners and allowees and information on the Savings Bonuses.
Information KitsDistributed to community groups, peak welfare organisations, Members of Parliament and customers making queries.

The Website contains general information about the portfolio's tax reform measures. The Website includes overviews, fact sheets and multilingual information (including information for self-funded retirees).
An article summarising information previously provided in Age Pension News about tax reform.

1.5 Million information pamphlets and claim forms for bonuses. Pamphlets provide full information on bonus program, including how the bonuses will be calculated, payment method and what customers need to do.

quote.para: Education and advertising material produced by the Australian Taxation Office also provided information about compensation for retirees.

subdebateinfo.title: Centrelink: Office Machines for Job Seekers
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1670)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 22 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) What agency is responsible for supplying facsimile machines, photocopiers and terminals for use by job seekers in Centrelink.
(2) What are the criteria used for calculating the number of facsimile machines and photocopiers supplied to each Centrelink Office for use by job seekers.
(3) What agency or contractor is responsible for the maintenance of the facsimile machines and photocopiers supplied to each Centrelink Office for use by job seekers.
(4) How many photocopiers have been provided for use by job seekers in the Centrelink offices in Innaloo and Mirrabooka, WA.
(5) How many facsimile machines have been provided for use by job seekers in the Centrelink offices in Innaloo and Mirrabooka.

(6) Does the agency or contractor which is responsible for the maintenance of the facsimile machines and photocopiers supplied to each Centrelink Office for use by job seekers keep records of maintenance costs and down-time; if so, (a) how many hours were job seekers left without the use of (i) photocopiers and (ii) facsimile machines at the (A) Innaloo and (B) Mirrabooka Centrelink offices in (I) 1996-97, (II) 1997-98 and (III) 1998-99.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) The Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business (DEWRSB) has overall responsibility to supply facsimile machines, photocopiers and terminals for use by job seekers in Centrelink. Different contractors provide equipment under DEWRSB contract. Those contracted agencies are :
. Copiers - Canon Australia,
. PC terminals and printers - IBM Global Services Australia, and
. Facsimile machines - Canon Australia in approximately 130 sites and, DEWRSB owned, ex-CES facsimile machines of various makes (Toshiba, Ricoh, Voca etc) in approximately 170 sites.

(2) DEWRSB provided one photocopier and one facsimile machine to each Centrelink Customer Service Centre and to selected Youth Servicing Units. The criteria for provision of this equipment was that the Customer Service Centre should be a permanent and full time site and that the Youth Servicing Unit should be located separately from the Customer Service Centre. Sites are able to request more facilities by completing a `Business Case Proforma' and forwarding this to DEWRSB. The decision to provide extra facilities is made by the Employment Self Help Steering Committee (made up of DEWRSB and Centrelink representatives).
(3) The following contractor or agency is responsible for the maintenance of:

. Photocopiers - Centrelink is responsible for reporting maintenance problems and toner replacement to Canon on a dedicated phone number. Canon (or it's contracted service providers) is then responsible for maintenance and replacement.

. Facsimile machines - If the facsimile is a Canon machine the same process is followed as applies to the photocopier (above). If an office holds an ex-CES machine, the Centrelink office is responsible for maintenance (replacement of drums, toner, paper and fixing) and must contact the local agent, according to the make of the machine. DEWRSB have agreed to replace these machines with the new Canon machines if it is more cost-efficient.
(4) There is one photocopier provided for use by job seekers in Innaloo Customer Service Centre and one photocopier provided for job seeker use in Mirrabooka Customer Service Centre.
(5) There is one facsimile machine provided for job seeker use in Innaloo Customer Service Centre and one facsimile machine provided for use in Mirrabooka Customer Service Centre.

(6) No official records are kept of photocopier or facsimile machine down-time at Innaloo and Mirrabooka offices by either the offices or those agencies contracted for maintenance. Canon reports indicate, however, that they had 19 maintenance call-outs to Innaloo office between January 1998 and June 2000 and 14 maintenance call-outs to Mirrabooka office between January 1998 and June 2000.

subdebateinfo.title: Eden Hill, Western Australia: Proposed Prison Site
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1723)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 29 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has the Minister received an application under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act from a Mrs Edna Bropho and others concerning the WA State Government placing a prison on an Aboriginal site at Eden Hill, Western Australia.
(2) Has the Minister requested Mr Peter Marks to report to him under subsection 10(4) of the Act.
(3) What qualifications does Mr Marks have to undertake such a reporting task.
(4) Is a prison a suitable institution to be established on land of special significance to the Aboriginal people of WA.
(5) Is the Minister aware that any approval by him to allow the prison to placed on the site will, in all probability, mean Aboriginal prisoners being placed in a prison on an Aboriginal sacred site.
(6) When will the Minister be in a position to take action to protect the Pyrton site against this proposed action by the WA Government.
(7) Will the Federal Government allow this insult to be visited on Aboriginal people by the WA Government.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr Truss
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes. I have received applications for protection, under both section 9 and section 10 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984, over the site of a proposed prison in the Eden Hill area.

(2) In line with the provisions of the Act, I have nominated Mr Peter Marks under s.10.(1)(c) of the Act to invite representations from interested persons, and to prepare a report to me on the matters prescribed in the Act. Mr Marks provided his report, along with representations made to him, on 6 June 2000.
(3) Mr Marks is an experienced lawyer and able to perform the functions prescribed in the provisions of the Act.
(4) and (5) These matters are dealt with in Mr Marks' report, which I am considering.

(6) and (7) I am required under the provisions of the Act to consider Mr Marks' report, the attached representations made to him, and any other relevant matters. When I have done so I will decide whether to make the declaration of protection sought by the applicants.
